questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following drugs is not hepatotoxic?
questions.explanation:
Cycloserine is not a hepatotoxic drug. The adverse effects of cycloserine are mainly neurological. Half of the patients on cycloserine (1g/day) experience neuropsychiatric symptoms. It ranges from 
headaches to psychosis, seizures, and suicidal ideas. Therefore, cycloserine is contraindicated in 
patients with epilepsy. Ethionamide, rifampicin, isoniazid and pyrazinamide are hepatotoxic agents. They are either 
contraindicated or used with extreme caution in hepatitis.

Question 2: A 24-year-old woman who was started on treatment for MDR-TB 6 months back, presented 
with complaints of fatigue, amenorrhea, and constipation since the past 1 month. On 
examination, a swelling was noticed on the anterior aspect of her neck. Her lab reports show 
raised TSH levels with low free T‹ and T4 levels. Which anti-tubercular drug is likely to cause 
this adverse effect?
questions.explanation:
578 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical features and lab reports are suggestive of hypothyroidism with goiter, which is a 
known adverse effect of ethionamide. MDR-TB is treated with 2nd line agents that include ethionamide (ETH). ETH is not a first-line 
agent due to its gastrointestinal side effects. It is structurally related to thionamides 
(propylthiouracil and methimazole) and therefore causes hypothyroidism by preventing 
organification of iodine in thyroid hormone synthesis. Another antitubercular drug that can cause 
hypothyroidism is Para-amino salicylic acid (PAS). ETH/PAS-induced hypothyroidism should be treated with thyroxine replacement therapy, instead 
of changing the regimen. Thyroid function usually optimizes within 2 months after completing 
MDR therapy.

questions.question: Question 3: What is the mechanism of anti-mycobacterial action of bedaquiline?
questions.explanation:
The mechanism of anti-mycobacterial action of bedaquiline is by inhibition of ATP synthase. Bedaquiline is a diarylquinoline that targets the subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. 
This leads to inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the 
bacillary energy metabolism.

questions.question:
Question 4: 575 
Sold by @itachibot A 68-year-old man with hypertension was diagnosed with drug-resistant pulmonary TB. One 
week after starting ATT he presented to the casualty following an episode of syncope. ECG 
showed a corrected QT interval of 477ms, which is shown below. Which drug used in his 
anti-tubercular therapy is responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with a corrected QT (QTc) interval of 477ms is suggestive of QTc 
prolongation which is an adverse effect associated with bedaquiline. In the ECG QTc (corrected QT interval= QT/RR) is 477ms. Normal QTc is about 440ms. Values 
of more than 440ms in males and 460ms in females are considered to be prolonged. QTc 
prolongation usually presents as syncope or cardiac arrest. Although QT prolongation can cause Torsades de pointes, no cases have been reported with 
bedaquiline. A 5-fold higher rate of death has been reported in patients on bedaquiline versus 
those on placebo. Therefore, the World Health Organization (WHO) advises caution when 
administering this medication. Bedaquiline is contraindicated in the age group of <18 years.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the mechanism of action of delamanid?
questions.explanation:
Delamanid acts by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis. Pretomanid and delamanid are bicyclic nitroimidazoles that act by inhibiting mycolic acid (a 
component of the mycobacterial cell wall) and protein synthesis in the mycobacteria. Pretomanid in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid was approved by FDA in 2019 for the 
treatment of adult patients with extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB and for patients who 
are treatment-intolerant or nonresponsive to multidrug-resistant pulmonary 
(MDR) TB treatment. 579 
Sold by @itachibot In India, delamanid is only approved for the management of MDR-TB. Isoniazid also acts by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis. Other options: Option A: Bedaquiline acts by inhibition of ATP synthase. It is a diarylquinoline that targets 
the subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. This leads to inhibition of the proton pump 
activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism. Option C: Fluoroquinolones act by inhibition of DNA gyrase. They are used as second-line agents 
in the treatment of tuberculosis. Option D: Cycloserine is a D-alanine analogue used as a second-line drug for MDR-TB that acts 
by inhibition of alanine racemase. Alanine racemase converts •-alanine to D-alanine which is 
needed for the mycobacterial cell wall.

Question 6: A ‹0-year-old pregnant woman was diagnosed with tuberculosis. Which of the following 
antitubercular drugs should not be used in her?
questions.explanation:
Streptomycin should not be used for the treatment of TB in a pregnant patient as it can cause 
hearing loss in the newborn. First-line treatment for tuberculosis in pregnancy is done with isoniazid(along with pyridoxine), 
rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide.

Question 7: An HIV-positive patient with a CD4 count of 40/mm‹ requires prophylaxis against M. avium 
complex bacteremia. Which of the following drugs would you prefer?
questions.explanation:
Azithromycin 1200 mg given once a week, is preferred for prophylactic therapy against 
bacteremia caused by Mycobacterium-avium complex (MAC) in people living with AIDS. Clarithromycin 500 mg twice daily, may also be administered for prophylaxis. Rifabutin ‹00 mg 
once daily is used for patients who are intolerant to macrolides. Prophylaxis is indicated when CD4 counts are less than 50/mm‹ and should be discontinued once 
the CD4 count is more than 100/mm‹. Dapsone is used as an alternative agent for prophylaxis of pneumocystis ™irovecii infection, 
whereas isoniazid is used for prophylaxis of mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.

Question 8: An elderly woman on ART with a CD4 count of ‹5/• and a high viral load presents with a 2 
week history of cough, fever, and night sweats. She was diagnosed with pulmonary M. avium 
complex infection. Which of the following is not included in the triple-drug therapy for the 
management of her condition?
questions.explanation:
Triple drug therapy for pulmonary Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infections does not 
include isoniazid. Treatment for pulmonary MAC infection is triple-drug therapy with: • A rifamycin, like rifampicin or rifabutin (In HIV patients on ART, rifabutin is preferred) • Ethambutol 580 
Sold by @itachibot • A macrolide, like clarithromycin or azithromycin MAC infection is an AIDS-defining opportunistic infection, occurring predominantly at CD4+ T 
cell counts of <50/• and high viral load. The average CD4+ T cell count at the time of diagnosis 
is 10/•. The most common presentation is disseminated disease with fever, weight loss, and 
night sweats.
